docs.lead_paragraph: LOCAL LAW 10, passed in New York City in 1980, requires owners of buildings higher than six stories to inspect them once every five years to insure that the facades are structurally safe. The next deadline is Feb. 21 -- and ''there's a lot of last-minute scrambling going on,'' said Alan S. Epstein, president of A. Epstein & Associates, a Manhattan engineering consulting company. ''It's shocking, but there are a lot of buildings out there that haven't even had their inspections done.'' Mr. Epstein said that since the law requires inspection reports for the more than 8,300 six-story-plus buildings in the city to be filed by the same deadline, those who have not already had their inspections completed by a registered architect or professional engineer will face the crunch that typically occurs at the end of each cycle.
docs.abstract: Article notes that February 21 is next deadline for compliance with New York City law that requires owners of buildings higher than six stories to inspect them once every five years to insure that facades are structurally safe; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a thousand feet below the snow-covered hills of northern Nevada, miners toil alone or in pairs in sweltering tunnels separated by absolute darkness. They are digging for gold. Tom Huhta and Dale Spring work the day shift at the Barrick Gold Corporation's Meikle mine. On a recent morning, sweat poured off their faces as they lifted a traditional two-man jackleg drill to install a metal brace to keep loose rock from falling on them. They were tunneling toward a huge pocket of ore estimated to contain 6.6 million ounces of gold. Steam whistled from cracks and fissures in the 140-degree rock walls. ''It's like an oven,'' Mr. Huhta said.

headline.main: Nevada Mining Shifts Underground to Get the Deep Ore

docs.abstract: Barrick Gold Corporation's underground mine in Carlin, Nev, is expected to produce 400,000 ounces of gold a year; photos; maps; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Attorney General Dan Morales of Texas filed suit yesterday seeking to block the merger of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois. The suit said Texas Blue Cross, a nonprofit corporation, was a charitable asset that could not be removed from the state. The merger plan, which was announced last summer, would combine companies with gross health premiums of $1.7 billion a year in Texas and $4.5 billion in Illinois, according to the suit, which was filed in a state court in Austin.

headline.main: Texas Sues To Halt Move By Blue Cross

docs.abstract: Atty Gen Dan Morales of Texas files suit seeking to block merger of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois; suit contends that Texas Blue Cross, a nonprofit corporation, is charitable asset that cannot be removed from the state; Illinois Blue Cross says it is a nonprofit mutual insurance company, which means it is owned by its policyholders, but Morales maintains that it is a for-profit entity as defined by Texas law; merger is subject to approval of insurance regulators in two states (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: John J. Sweeney is sounding unmistakably upbeat nowadays even though Republicans assert that big labor was the big loser in last week's elections. Mr. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, admits to some disappointment that the Democrats failed to regain the House despite labor's anti-Republican advertising blitz and its mobilizing of thousands of campaign foot soldiers. But in what critics are calling instant historical revisionism, he says taking back the House was never labor's main goal.

headline.main: Despite Setbacks, Labor Chief Is Upbeat Over Election Role

docs.abstract: Interview with AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney; admits disappointment that Democrats failed to regain control of House despite organization's advertising blitz, but says taking back House was never labor's main goal; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to fend off Federal regulation, officials of managed health care plans said today that they would cover at least one night's hospital care for women who undergo mastectomies. The American Association of Health Plans, the leading trade group for health maintenance organizations and other managed care plans, said its members ''do not and should not require outpatient care for removal of a breast.''

headline.main: Managed Care Officials Agree To Mastectomy Hospital Stays

docs.abstract: Officials of managed-care health plans, hoping to fend off Federal regulation, agree to cover at least one night's hospital care for women who undergo mastectomies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sun America Inc. said yesterday that it would buy $5 billion worth of annuity reserves from the John Alden Financial Corporation for undisclosed terms. The acquisition would include substantially all of John Alden's annuity business and comes as the company focuses on its health insurance business, said Chris Wells, a spokeswoman for John Alden, which is based in Miami. The company said in March that it would sell its annuity and credit life and disability units. Sun America, based in Los Angeles, recently said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was considering a purchase worth $200 million to $300 million, said Karel Carnohan, a Sun America vice president. Analysts in March estimated John Alden's annuity business could fetch $275 million.

headline.main: SUN AMERICA IS BUYING ANNUITY RESERVES FROM JOHN ALDEN

docs.abstract: Sun America Inc says it will buy $5 billion worth of annuity reserves from John Alden Financial Corp for undisclosed terms; acquisition will include substantially all of John Alden's annuity business (S)
